identificationModule.briefTitle: Enhancing Strength Gains With the Power of the Mind
identificationModule.officialTitle: The Effect of Combining Maximal Mental Effort With Elastic Band Training on Strength and Neuromuscular Adaptations in Older Females

descriptionModule.briefSummary:
The goal of this clinical trial is to determine the effect of maximal mental effort combined with elastic band training on strength and neuromuscular function in healthy, older females. The main questions it aims to answer are:

* Does elastic band training in combination with maximal mental effort increase strength more than elastic band training alone?
* Does elastic band training in combination with maximal mental effort improve neuromuscular function more than elastic band training alone?

Participants will be randomly assigned to 1 of 3 groups:

* Elastic band training
* Elastic band training with maximal mental effort
* Control

Researchers will compare groups to determine differences in changes in strength, neuromuscular function, and body composition.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
Participants in both training groups will perform 6 weeks of moderate intensity, whole-body elastic band training. Participants in the control group will participate in all testing procedures but not perform any training. Participants from both groups will be instructed to maintain their normal physical activity levels and dietary habits.

All training sessions will be home-based and virtually supervised by research personnel. Participants will complete 2 training sessions in the first week and 3 training sessions per week for the remaining 5 weeks. Each training session will last about 45-60 minutes and consist of 7 exercises performed in the same order by each participant, including both multi-joint (chair squat, chest press, leg press, back row) and single-joint (knee extension, knee flexion, elbow flexion) exercises. Participants will perform 12 repetitions for each exercise for the first 3 weeks, then volume will be increased by progressing to 4 sets for the remaining 3 weeks. There will be a 60-second rest interval between sets and a similar tempo will be used between groups.

Both training groups will perform the same training protocol, but participants in the maximal mental effort group will mentally urge their muscles to contract maximally during each repetition. That is, despite using a moderate intensity, participants will imagine the feeling of maximal muscle contraction of the primary muscles during each repetition.

Several measures of strength, neuromuscular function, physical function, and body composition will be measured before and after the training or control period.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: Two intervention groups will perform different types of elastic band training, and a control group will not perform any elastic band training.

maskingInfo.maskingDescription: The mental effort aspect of the study will be concealed from subjects, so they will not be aware of any difference between training groups.

armGroups.label: Elastic Band Training
armGroups.description: This group will perform moderate intensity, whole-body elastic band training.

armGroups.label: Elastic Band Training with Maximal Mental Effort
armGroups.description: This group will perform moderate intensity, whole-body elastic band training with maximal mental effort during muscle contraction.
interventionNames: Behavioral: Elastic Band Training with Maximal Mental Effort

armGroups.label: Control
armGroups.description: This group will not perform any training and maintain their regular level of physical activity.

interventions.name: Elastic Band Training
interventions.description: This training intervention will be 6 weeks of moderate-intensity elastic band training, including whole-body and isolated muscle exercises.

interventions.name: Elastic Band Training with Maximal Mental Effort
interventions.description: This training intervention will be 6 weeks of moderate-intensity elastic band training, including whole-body and isolated muscle exercises, where participants will perform maximal mental effort by imagining maximal muscle contraction during each exercise.
armGroupLabels: Elastic Band Training with Maximal Mental Effort

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in bicep curl strength as measured by load lifted in pounds
primaryOutcomes.description: Maximum dumbbell load lifted successfully throughout the range of motion of a bicep curl

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in voluntary activation as measured by ratio of superimposed torque to resting twitch torque
secondaryOutcomes.description: Voluntary activation is an estimate of neural drive and is the amplitude of superimposed torque elicited by percutaneous muscle stimulation relative to the resting twitch torque amplitude

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in handgrip strength as measured in kilograms of force
secondaryOutcomes.description: Upper-body strength as measured by a handgrip dynamometer

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in agonist muscle activation as measured by electromyography amplitude
secondaryOutcomes.description: A measure of the capacity at which the muscle is activitated by the nervous system

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change from baseline in isokinetic muscle activation at 6 weeks
secondaryOutcomes.description: Electromyography root mean square during isokinetic contraction divided by root mean square during isometric contraction

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in antagonist co-activation as measured by electromyography amplitude
secondaryOutcomes.description: A measure of the capacity at which the antagonist muscle is activated by the nervous system

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in isometric bicep strength as measured by newton-meters of torque
secondaryOutcomes.description: Isometric strength of a muscle

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in isokinetic bicep strength as measured by newton-meters of torque
secondaryOutcomes.description: Dynamic strength of a muscle contracting at a constant velocity

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in rate of torque development as measured by newton-meters per second
secondaryOutcomes.description: A measure of the capacity to increase muscle torque rapidly as determined by the slope of the torque-time curve

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in walking speed as measured by time taken to walk 6 meters
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measure of lower-body physical function

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in chair rise performance as measured by number of chair rises performed in 30 seconds
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measure of lower-body physical function

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in chair rise power by watts by a linear transducer attached to hip during chair rise test
secondaryOutcomes.description: Product of load and velocity as determined on a linear transducer

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in muscle composition as measured by ultrasound-derived grey-scale analysis
secondaryOutcomes.description: Echo-intensity value derived from grey-scale analysis is indicative of amount of non-contractile tissue in muscle

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in skeletal muscle size as measured by ultrasound-derived cross-sectional
secondaryOutcomes.description: Size of a muscle

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in fat mass as measured by kilograms
secondaryOutcomes.description: Amount of fat tissue a person possesses estimated by bioelectrical impedance analysis

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in fat-free mass as measured by kilograms
secondaryOutcomes.description: Amount of non-fat tissue a person possesses estimated by bioelectrical impedance analysis

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in body fat percentage as measured by fat tissue relative to fat-free tissue
secondaryOutcomes.description: Relative amount of body fat a person possesses estimated by bioelectrical impedance analysis

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in hemoglobin A1c level as measured by blood drop analysis
secondaryOutcomes.description: Blood drop analysis, obtained from fingerstick, measure of amount of blood sugar bound to hemoglobin

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in resting heart rate as measured by beats/min using oscillatory cuff
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measure of cardiovascular fitness

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in resting blood pressure in millimeters of mercury using oscillatory cuff
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measure of cardiovascular fitness

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in general feeling about knee extension and bicep curl exercise
secondaryOutcomes.description: From a -5 to +5 on the Affective Feeling Scale
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Each exercise session of the 6-week intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in grip width on elastic band as measured by distance of hand placements on band
secondaryOutcomes.description: Indication of progression in training intensity

otherOutcomes.description: A descriptor of the exercise physiological intensity for both training protocols
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: Each exercise session of the 6-week intervention

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in calorie consumption as measured by kilocalories determined by dietary recall
Change in protein consumption as measured by kilocalories determined by dietary recall
Change in physical activity as measured by daily step count via Garmin Venu SQ smartwatch

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Between 65-79 years of age
* Female
* Have not engaged in structured exercise for 3 years
* Are not reliant upon a walking aid
* Be able to rise from a chair unassisted
* BMI between 25-33 kg/m²
* Have access to the internet and access to a smartphone or computer with a camera at home

Exclusion Criteria:

* Any history of cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, or metabolic diseases
* Musculoskeletal injury within the past 6 months
* Any condition affecting muscle function
* Uncontrolled hypertension
* Score less than 23 on the Mini-mental State Exam
* Upon starting study, missing more than 2 training session
